prior_works.title: Evaluating Derivatives: Principles and Techniques of Algorithmic Differentiation (2nd ed.)
prior_works.role: Foundational AD theory and cost models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the computational-graph view of AD, reverse/forward accumulation, and operation-count cost models that underlie framing Jacobian accumulation as an elimination ordering problem exploited by cross-country elimination.

prior_works.title: Optimal Jacobian Accumulation Is NP-Complete
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Proved the combinatorial hardness of finding optimal Jacobian accumulation orders, directly motivating the paper’s use of learned (RL) search to discover near-optimal elimination orders that minimize multiplications while preserving exactness.

prior_works.title: The Art of Differentiating Programs: An Introduction to Algorithmic Differentiation
prior_works.role: Algorithmic techniques for exact Jacobian accumulation (edge/vertex elimination, sparsity)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Detailed exact Jacobian/Hessian accumulation strategies (e.g., edge pushing, vertex elimination, and sparsity exploitation) and associated cost accounting, providing the practical foundations that cross-country elimination systematizes and that the RL agent optimizes over.

prior_works.title: Bucket Elimination: A Unifying Framework for Probabilistic Inference
prior_works.role: Ordered elimination on graphs and cost sensitivity to elimination order
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the ordered-elimination paradigm on graphical models, clarifying how elimination order drives computational cost—an insight directly mirrored in cross-country elimination’s vertex-ordering objective for Jacobian accumulation.

prior_works.title: What Color Is Your Jacobian? Graph Coloring for Computing Derivatives
prior_works.authors: Assefaw H. Gebremedhin, Fredrik Manne, Alex Pothen
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that graph-theoretic structure can drastically reduce derivative computation cost, reinforcing the paper’s strategy to leverage graph structure and ordering (via RL) to minimize multiplications without sacrificing exactness.

prior_works.title: Discovering faster matrix multiplication algorithms with reinforcement learning (AlphaTensor)
prior_works.role: RL for discovering exact algorithms minimizing multiplications
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed deep RL can discover provably exact algorithms with fewer multiplications, directly inspiring the use of RL to search the discrete space of elimination orders to reduce exact Jacobian accumulation cost.

prior_works.title: Neural Combinatorial Optimization with Reinforcement Learning
prior_works.authors: William R. Bello, Hieu Pham, Quoc V. Le, Mohammad Norouzi, Samy Bengio
prior_works.role: RL for discrete sequence/ordering problems on graphs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided a blueprint for training RL agents to construct permutation-like solutions in combinatorial spaces, analogous to learning high-quality elimination orders over computational graphs in cross-country elimination.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core idea—using deep reinforcement learning to minimize the number of multiplications required for exact Jacobian computation by optimizing a cross-country elimination order—sits at the intersection of algorithmic differentiation (AD), graph-elimination theory, and learning-based search for combinatorial algorithms. Griewank and Walther’s AD foundations established Jacobian accumulation on computational graphs and the precise accounting of arithmetic costs, while Naumann’s work both codified practical accumulation techniques (edge/vertex elimination, sparsity exploitation) and proved the NP-completeness of optimal Jacobian accumulation. These results crystallize the problem as one of choosing elimination orders whose costs can vary dramatically yet resist exact polynomial-time optimization, creating a natural opening for data-driven search.

Dechter’s bucket elimination formalized how ordered elimination in graphical models dictates computational burden, a perspective mirrored by cross-country elimination’s cost-driven vertex ordering. Complementing this, Gebremedhin–Manne–Pothen showed that graph structure can be leveraged to compress derivative computations, reinforcing the importance of structural heuristics that an RL policy can learn to exploit.

On the learning side, AlphaTensor demonstrated that deep RL can discover exact algorithms with fewer multiplications, directly paralleling the paper’s objective but applied to Jacobian accumulation rather than matrix multiplication. Neural combinatorial optimization with RL provided effective mechanisms for learning permutation-like solutions over graphs, guiding how to parameterize the policy, rewards, and search for elimination orders. Together, these works enable the paper’s contribution: an RL-driven optimizer over the cross-country elimination space that preserves exactness while reducing multiplication counts in Jacobian evaluation.
